docs.title: Introduction to DNS Tool
docs.text: DNS Tool is a command-line utility for network administrators, security researchers, and IT professionals. It simplifies the verification of DNS records like DMARC, SPF, DKIM, and DNSSEC, providing real-time feedback to enhance email security and prevent spoofing.

docs.title: Main Features
docs.text:
• Comprehensive DNS Checks: Access all key DNS records in one place: NS, A/AAAA, MX, TXT, SPF, DMARC, DKIM, and more. 🌐
  • Interactive & Batch Modes: Use an interactive prompt with arrow-key history or batch mode for multiple domains. 🔄
  • Colorful Output: Identify issues quickly with highlights using ✅, ❌, ⚠️ for clear guidance.

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
1. Download the dnstool binary from GitHub Releases.
  2. Make the file executable: chmod +x dnstool
  3. Run it: ./dnstool

Visit the Installation and Setup page for instructions on other operating systems.

Start using DNS Tool by visiting the Getting Started guide.

docs.title: Installation and Setup
docs.text: Welcome to the Installation and Setup guide for the DNS Tool, a command-line utility for DNS and email security validation. Follow these steps to get DNS Tool running on your Linux, macOS, or Windows machine.

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
1. Download the dnstool binary from the GitHub Releases.
  2. Make the binary executable: bash chmod +x dnstool
  3. Run the tool: bash ./dnstool
  4. Optional: Move the binary to a directory in your PATH: bash sudo mv dnstool /usr/local/bin

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
1. Download dnstool_macos from the Releases.
  2. Allow execution via Terminal: bash chmod +x dnstool_macos xattr -r -d com.apple.quarantine ./dnstool_macos
  3. Run: bash ./dnstool_macos

Alternatively, right-click in Finder → Open → Click Open Anyway via Security & Privacy settings.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Download dnstool.exe from the Releases.
  2. Execute in Command Prompt / PowerShell: powershell .\dnstool.exe
  3. If warned by SmartScreen, click "More info → Run anyway."

You are now ready to use DNS Tool, see the Getting Started guide for next steps.

docs.title: Usage and Examples
docs.text: This guide will show you how to get started with DNS Tool. It will showcase how to use the tool in both interactive and batch modes, with example commands and output descriptions.

docs.title: Interactive Mode 🌟
docs.text:
Interactive mode is straightforward to use. To enter this mode, run the following command:

./dnstool

You’ll see a prompt where you can enter a domain, press Enter, and DNS Tool will perform a DNS check.

The output is color-coded: ✅ for success, ❌ for failure, and ⚠️ for warnings.

docs.title: Example Command
docs.text:
Run ./dnstool to start the interactive mode:

./dnstool

Then just enter a domain:

Domain:
example.com

You will then get color-coded output, such as:

✅ NS: OK
❌ SPF: Missing
⚠️ DMARC: p=none

This design can help to quickly spot configuration issues.

docs.title: Batch Mode 🚀
docs.text: Batch mode allows you to check multiple domains simultaneously. Provide domain names as command-line arguments or via a file.

docs.title: File Input
docs.text:
./dnstool -f domains.txt

This mode is ideal for managing multiple domains or integrating checks into workflows.

docs.title: Verbose Output 🛠️
docs.text:
For detailed insights, use the -v flag for verbose output.

./dnstool -v example.com

This provides detailed debug information, useful for troubleshooting or understanding the tool’s processes.

For full details and features, refer to the main documentation here.
